classes.title: GLBL88.
classes.subtitle: First-Year Seminar: Beg, Borrow, and Steal: The Political Economy of Aid, FDI, and Corruption.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This seminar examines how politics and economics condition different countries' path towards and experience with foreign aid, foreign investment, and corruption. In doing so, the course will examine the effect of political conditions on economic outcomes and the effect of economic conditions on political outcomes.Gen Ed: SS, GL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL89.
classes.subtitle: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This seminar examines how politics and economics condition different countries' path towards and experience with foreign aid, foreign investment, and corruption. In doing so, the course will examine the effect of political conditions on economic outcomes and the effect of economic conditions on political outcomes.Gen Ed: SS, GL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL89.
classes.subtitle: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Special topics course.  Content will vary each semester. Honors version availableRepeat rules: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 6 total credits. 2 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL110
classes.subtitle: Global Policy Issues.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Special topics course.  Content will vary each semester. Honors version availableRepeat rules: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 6 total credits. 2 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL110
classes.subtitle: Global Policy Issues.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Global issues are challenges whose sources, impacts, and solutions extend beyond the borders of any one country. Honors version availableGen Ed: SS, GL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: PLCY�110, PWAD�110.

classes.subtitle: Teaching Great Decisions.  1 Credit.

classes.subtitle: Independent Study.  1-12 Credits.

classes.subtitle: Global Issues and Globalization.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. Reading and research on special topics in global studies.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit. 12 total credits. 4 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL210
classes.subtitle: Global Issues and Globalization.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Survey of international social, political, and cultural patterns in selected societies of Africa, Asia, America, and Europe, stressing comparative analysis of conflicts and change in different historical contexts. classes.subtitle: Phillips Ambassadors Program.  3 Credits.

LAC recitation sections offered in French, German, and Spanish.Gen Ed: GL.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: ANTH�210, GEOG�210, HIST�210, POLI�210.

classes.title: GLBL281
classes.subtitle: Phillips Ambassadors Program.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This academic course is mandatory for Phillips Ambassadors. Course open only to Phillips Ambassadors.Gen Ed: BN.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL290
classes.subtitle: Current Topics in Global Studies.  0.5-21 Credits.
classes.description: This academic course is mandatory for Phillips Ambassadors. Course open only to Phillips Ambassadors.Gen Ed: BN.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL290
classes.subtitle: Current Topics in Global Studies.  0.5-21 Credits.
classes.description: An interdisciplinary approach to the study of the background, current status, and future prospects for one of a series of global issues such as the nuclear age, the environment, technological transition.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL381
classes.subtitle: Great Decisions.  1 Credit.
classes.description: An interdisciplinary approach to the study of the background, current status, and future prospects for one of a series of global issues such as the nuclear age, the environment, technological transition.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL381
classes.subtitle: Great Decisions.  1 Credit.
classes.description: Eight evening guest lectures, with a discussion session after each, on eight issues in current foreign policy. May be repeated for credit. Students may not receive credit for both GLBL�381 and POLI�381.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit. 3 total credits. 3 total completions.Grading status: Pass/Fail.

classes.title: GLBL382
classes.subtitle: Latin American Migrant Perspectives: Ethnography and Action.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Eight evening guest lectures, with a discussion session after each, on eight issues in current foreign policy. May be repeated for credit. Students may not receive credit for both GLBL�381 and POLI�381.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit. 3 total credits. 3 total completions.Grading status: Pass/Fail.

classes.title: GLBL382
classes.subtitle: Latin American Migrant Perspectives: Ethnography and Action.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This class combines fieldwork, oral history, and service learning in a course that examines concepts of globalization, migration, and transnationalism, and their intersections with anthropological theory and practice.Gen Ed: EE- Field Work.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL383
classes.subtitle: Global Whiteness.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This class combines fieldwork, oral history, and service learning in a course that examines concepts of globalization, migration, and transnationalism, and their intersections with anthropological theory and practice.Gen Ed: EE- Field Work.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL383
classes.subtitle: Global Whiteness.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course looks at race as a theory and practice as it has been constructed in academic disciplines, popular culture, and social struggle.Gen Ed: HS, GL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL390
classes.subtitle: Current Topics in Global Studies.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course looks at race as a theory and practice as it has been constructed in academic disciplines, popular culture, and social struggle.Gen Ed: HS, GL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL390
classes.subtitle: Current Topics in Global Studies.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Topics vary from semester to semester.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 12 total credits. 4 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL394
classes.subtitle: Great Decisions and International Relations.  2 Credits.
classes.description: Topics vary from semester to semester.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit; may be repeated in the same term for different topics; 12 total credits. 4 total completions.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL394
classes.subtitle: Great Decisions and International Relations.  2 Credits.
classes.description: This course links the Great Decisions lecture series with readings and analyses of international relations. Its purpose is to provide the students on the Great Decisions coordinating committee with a practical and intellectual engagement with United States foreign policy and global issues.Requisites: Pre- or corequisite, GLBL�381.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 3 total completions.Grading status: Pass/Fail.

classes.title: GLBL401
classes.subtitle: Paradigms of Development and Social Change.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course links the Great Decisions lecture series with readings and analyses of international relations. Its purpose is to provide the students on the Great Decisions coordinating committee with a practical and intellectual engagement with United States foreign policy and global issues.Requisites: Pre- or corequisite, GLBL�381.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit. 6 total credits. 3 total completions.Grading status: Pass/Fail.

classes.title: GLBL401
classes.subtitle: Paradigms of Development and Social Change.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course aims to develop a critical perspective on development -- understood as a cultural logic and a discreet set of practices and policies -- so that we can better contribute to positive social change. Through course material and service learning, students develop an understanding of the relationship between development projects and emancipatory frameworks. Honors version availableGen Ed: EE- Service Learning.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL413
classes.subtitle: Socialist and Decolonial Ecologies.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course aims to develop a critical perspective on development -- understood as a cultural logic and a discreet set of practices and policies -- so that we can better contribute to positive social change. Through course material and service learning, students develop an understanding of the relationship between development projects and emancipatory frameworks. Honors version availableGen Ed: EE- Service Learning.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL413
classes.subtitle: Socialist and Decolonial Ecologies.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course will focus on the relation of capitalism and anthropogenic climate change and feature Marxist and Indigenous critiques of capitalism's responsibility for climate change. We will feature an interdisciplinary lens - philosophy, feminist geography, cultural anthropology, socialist economics - that will analyze how the anthropocentric subject of the Enlightenment separated itself from its natural environment.Requisites: Prerequisite, GLBL�210.Gen Ed: BN.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL415
classes.subtitle: Dealing with Difference: Criminal Justice, Race, and Social Movements in Globalization.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course will focus on the relation of capitalism and anthropogenic climate change and feature Marxist and Indigenous critiques of capitalism's responsibility for climate change. We will feature an interdisciplinary lens - philosophy, feminist geography, cultural anthropology, socialist economics - that will analyze how the anthropocentric subject of the Enlightenment separated itself from its natural environment.Requisites: Prerequisite, GLBL�210.Gen Ed: BN.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL415
classes.subtitle: Dealing with Difference: Criminal Justice, Race, and Social Movements in Globalization.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Recommended preparation, GLBL�210. This course is dedicated to understanding how sameness and difference are used and contested globally, in particular through the criminal justice system and its intersection with race and capitalism. The course pays particular attention to popular social movement responses, and what they say to theories of difference, globalization, and social change.Gen Ed: GL, US.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL450
classes.subtitle: Social Change in Times of Crisis: Knowledge, Action, and Ontology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Recommended preparation, GLBL�210. This course is dedicated to understanding how sameness and difference are used and contested globally, in particular through the criminal justice system and its intersection with race and capitalism. The course pays particular attention to popular social movement responses, and what they say to theories of difference, globalization, and social change.Gen Ed: GL, US.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL450
classes.subtitle: Social Change in Times of Crisis: Knowledge, Action, and Ontology.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Examines dominant, alternative, and emergent narratives of change and the future from around the world. Takes as a premise that we live in a period of multidimensional crises characterized by uncertainty and conflict about how to pursue sustainable economic, ecological, political, social, and cultural projects.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL481
classes.subtitle: NGO Politics.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Examines dominant, alternative, and emergent narratives of change and the future from around the world. Takes as a premise that we live in a period of multidimensional crises characterized by uncertainty and conflict about how to pursue sustainable economic, ecological, political, social, and cultural projects.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL481
classes.subtitle: NGO Politics.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course will investigate how nongovernmental organizations emerge, how they structure their organizations, how they function, and how they influence public policy. Honors version availableGrading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL482
classes.subtitle: Soviet and Post-Soviet Politics and Institutions.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course will investigate how nongovernmental organizations emerge, how they structure their organizations, how they function, and how they influence public policy. Honors version availableGrading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL482
classes.subtitle: Soviet and Post-Soviet Politics and Institutions.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course is an introduction to the history and contemporary politics of the post-Soviet region and explores topics of religious, ethnic, and identity politics; international influences; and civil society and social movements. Honors version availableGrading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL483
classes.subtitle: Comparative Health Systems.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course is an introduction to the history and contemporary politics of the post-Soviet region and explores topics of religious, ethnic, and identity politics; international influences; and civil society and social movements. Honors version availableGrading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL483
classes.subtitle: Comparative Health Systems.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course provides students with an understanding of the origins and comparative performance of a range of international healthcare systems. Honors version availableGrading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL484
classes.subtitle: History and Politics of Central Asia.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course provides students with an understanding of the origins and comparative performance of a range of international healthcare systems. Honors version availableGrading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL484
classes.subtitle: History and Politics of Central Asia.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course is an introduction of the history, politics, and societies of Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan. The class explores the foundations and conditions of change in the modern history of these societies and investigates how these issues influence contemporary politics.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL485
classes.subtitle: Comparative Development.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course is an introduction of the history, politics, and societies of Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Turkmenistan, and Uzbekistan. The class explores the foundations and conditions of change in the modern history of these societies and investigates how these issues influence contemporary politics.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL485
classes.subtitle: Comparative Development.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course is an APPLES service-learning course whose goal is to integrate real-world experience working with development-oriented organizations, theoretical discussions about the origins and evolution of development thinking, and exposure to the challenges facing practitioners of development, in some of its many substantive and geographical contexts.Gen Ed: EE- Service Learning.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL486
classes.subtitle: Sports and Globalization.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course is an APPLES service-learning course whose goal is to integrate real-world experience working with development-oriented organizations, theoretical discussions about the origins and evolution of development thinking, and exposure to the challenges facing practitioners of development, in some of its many substantive and geographical contexts.Gen Ed: EE- Service Learning.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL486
classes.subtitle: Sports and Globalization.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course explores some of the relationships between sports and globalization and will delve into sports as an important social and cultural practice within larger social, cultural, and political forces shaping studies of globalization. Honors version availableGrading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL487
classes.subtitle: Social Movements: Rethinking Globalization.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course explores some of the relationships between sports and globalization and will delve into sports as an important social and cultural practice within larger social, cultural, and political forces shaping studies of globalization. Honors version availableGrading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL487
classes.subtitle: Social Movements: Rethinking Globalization.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course explores the history, objectives, and manifestations of global social movements. Honors version availableGrading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL489
classes.subtitle: Paradigms of Development and Social Change.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course explores the history, objectives, and manifestations of global social movements. Honors version availableGrading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL489
classes.subtitle: Paradigms of Development and Social Change.  3 Credits.
classes.description: By deliberately juxtaposing questions of global development with an investigation of approaches in community organizing locally--both through course material and service-learning assignments--the course encourages students to develop a more critical understanding of the relationship between development projects and emancipatory frameworks.Gen Ed: BN, EE- Service Learning.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL490
classes.subtitle: Current Topics.  3 Credits.
classes.description: By deliberately juxtaposing questions of global development with an investigation of approaches in community organizing locally--both through course material and service-learning assignments--the course encourages students to develop a more critical understanding of the relationship between development projects and emancipatory frameworks.Gen Ed: BN, EE- Service Learning.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL490
classes.subtitle: Current Topics.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Current topics in international and area studies.  Topics vary by semester.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL491
classes.subtitle: Major Controversies in Human Rights.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Current topics in international and area studies.  Topics vary by semester.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL491
classes.subtitle: Major Controversies in Human Rights.  3 Credits.
classes.description: A forum for exploring conceptual and practical problems related to the emergence of a global human rights regime after World War II. The course analyzes relevant arguments, and students will consider whether it is possible to construct a coherent, workable, universally accepted system for articulating and enforcing human rights norms.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL492
classes.subtitle: Global Food Films.  3 Credits.
classes.description: A forum for exploring conceptual and practical problems related to the emergence of a global human rights regime after World War II. The course analyzes relevant arguments, and students will consider whether it is possible to construct a coherent, workable, universally accepted system for articulating and enforcing human rights norms.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL492
classes.subtitle: Global Food Films.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Thinking about one of our most basic human needs illuminates aspects of our own everyday lives, such as our relationship to nature, other cultures, and to history, as well as our general assumptions about humanity. Students will study films that explore cross-cultural differences in the social and philosophical understandings of what it is to be human. Honors version availableGen Ed: VP.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL560
classes.subtitle: Human Rights, Ethics, and Global Issues.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Thinking about one of our most basic human needs illuminates aspects of our own everyday lives, such as our relationship to nature, other cultures, and to history, as well as our general assumptions about humanity. Students will study films that explore cross-cultural differences in the social and philosophical understandings of what it is to be human. Honors version availableGen Ed: VP.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL560
classes.subtitle: Human Rights, Ethics, and Global Issues.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This seminar examines the political, economic and intellectual developments that led to the emergence of human rights as a global phenomenon historically and in the current phase of globalization. Also engages with debates concerning the role of human rights as an ethical philosophy in thinking through global issues.Gen Ed: GL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL691
classes.subtitle: Honors in Global Studies.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This seminar examines the political, economic and intellectual developments that led to the emergence of human rights as a global phenomenon historically and in the current phase of globalization. Also engages with debates concerning the role of human rights as an ethical philosophy in thinking through global issues.Gen Ed: GL.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL691
classes.subtitle: Honors in Global Studies.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. Preparation for writing the honors thesis.Gen Ed: EE- Mentored Research.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL692
classes.subtitle: Honors in Global Studies.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. Preparation for writing the honors thesis.Gen Ed: EE- Mentored Research.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL692
classes.subtitle: Honors in Global Studies.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. Completion of the honors thesis and an oral examination of the thesis.Gen Ed: EE- Mentored Research.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL700
classes.subtitle: Introduction to Research and Theory in Global Studies.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Permission of the instructor. Completion of the honors thesis and an oral examination of the thesis.Gen Ed: EE- Mentored Research.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL700
classes.subtitle: Introduction to Research and Theory in Global Studies.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Global studies examines world systems, transnational processes, and global-local interactions from a multi-disciplinary perspective. This course will introduce students to current interdisciplinary theoretical approaches to global studies and examine the primary topics of contemporary research relating to the rise of a complex but increasingly integrated world society.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL701
classes.subtitle: Political Economy of Development.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Global studies examines world systems, transnational processes, and global-local interactions from a multi-disciplinary perspective. This course will introduce students to current interdisciplinary theoretical approaches to global studies and examine the primary topics of contemporary research relating to the rise of a complex but increasingly integrated world society.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL701
classes.subtitle: Political Economy of Development.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Presents foundational theories, concepts, and empirical research regarding the political economy of development. In content, course will define this topic broadly, from considering the political and economic dynamics of the international community (e.g., aid) as well as the intersection of economics and politics in comparative perspective (e.g., democratization and development).Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL702
classes.subtitle: Global Politics, Institutions, and Societies.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Presents foundational theories, concepts, and empirical research regarding the political economy of development. In content, course will define this topic broadly, from considering the political and economic dynamics of the international community (e.g., aid) as well as the intersection of economics and politics in comparative perspective (e.g., democratization and development).Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL702
classes.subtitle: Global Politics, Institutions, and Societies.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course will address global governance and global public policy; interactions among states, international organizations, businesses, social movements, and NGOs. It addresses the diffusion and promotion of democracy and other norms and the interactions between political institutions and social cleavages. Students with this concentration must take one appropriate methodology class.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL703
classes.subtitle: Global Migration and Labor Rights.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This course will address global governance and global public policy; interactions among states, international organizations, businesses, social movements, and NGOs. It addresses the diffusion and promotion of democracy and other norms and the interactions between political institutions and social cleavages. Students with this concentration must take one appropriate methodology class.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL703
classes.subtitle: Global Migration and Labor Rights.  3 Credits.
classes.description: The course will focus on the interactions of migration, labor rights, human rights, economics, health disparities, and cross-border tensions. Students with this concentration will also take at least one appropriate disciplinary methodology class.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL710
classes.subtitle: Monitoring and Evaluation for Peacebuilding Interventions.  2 Credits.
classes.description: The course will focus on the interactions of migration, labor rights, human rights, economics, health disparities, and cross-border tensions. Students with this concentration will also take at least one appropriate disciplinary methodology class.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL710
classes.subtitle: Monitoring and Evaluation for Peacebuilding Interventions.  2 Credits.
classes.description: This introductory course offers a review of the core concepts, skills and practical steps in monitoring and evaluation of coexistence and peacebuilding interventions. The course will stress participatory methods in monitoring and evaluation, in which multiple stakeholders are involved in the process of planning, collecting, interpreting, synthesizing, and using information. The course will feature case studies, proposals, and organizational evaluation plans and reports.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL730
classes.subtitle: Identities and Transitions.  3 Credits.
classes.description: This introductory course offers a review of the core concepts, skills and practical steps in monitoring and evaluation of coexistence and peacebuilding interventions. The course will stress participatory methods in monitoring and evaluation, in which multiple stakeholders are involved in the process of planning, collecting, interpreting, synthesizing, and using information. The course will feature case studies, proposals, and organizational evaluation plans and reports.Grading status: Letter grade.

classes.title: GLBL730
classes.subtitle: Identities and Transitions.  3 Credits.
classes.description: Capstone course for the REEES concentration in the Global Studies MA program. Interdisciplinary course focusing on the variety of problems encountered by the societies of East European countries and successor states of the former Soviet Union in their transition from communism to democracy.Grading status: Letter gradeSame as: POLI�746.

classes.subtitle: Master's Research and Thesis.  3-6 Credits.
classes.description: Master's thesis substitute paper; permission of the instructor required.Repeat rules: May be repeated for credit.

classes.title: GLBL993
classes.subtitle: Master's Research and Thesis.  3-6 Credits.
